abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Technical
            Assistance Project for Zambia were as follows: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory, project sustainability was unlikely, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:  first, in
            the event of a hiatus in project implementation, the project
            should be completely reformulated or canceled at the end of
            the hiatus. Second, to ensure proper implementation, someone
            should be deployed full-time to manage the project. Third,
            project salaries of locally recruited consultants  should be
            such as not to demoralize non-project staff and one that the
            country can comfortably support even without donor funding,
            by maintaining a unified, but rewarding pay structure.
            Fourth, a monitoring unit working with measurable indicators
            is essential to guide implementation and ensure success of
            the project. Fifth, effective project supervision from the
            Bank is indispensable to project success, by clearly
            identifying and addressing problems. Finally, capacity
            building should be an integral part of all projects in Africa.

docna.cdata!:
Zambia - Second Technical Assistance Project
            : Credit 1679 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Zambia - Second Technical
            Assistance Project : Credit 1679 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Technical Assistance Project
            will address two major weaknesses in development
            administration in Zambia which include: (a) inadequate
            capacity to carry out macroeconomic analysis; and (b) the
            lack of timely and accurate financial information required
            for analysis and the efficient management of the economy.
            Related to these two main aid objectives, the project will
            also strengthen the processes of budget preparation and
            revenue estimation and improve coordination between planning
            and budgeting. Specifically, the project would provide: (i)
            macroeconomic analysis; (ii) a financial management system;
            (iii) budget and revenue specialists; as well as (iv)
            training; and (v) follow-up services to Technical Assistance I.
